title: 105_s2035
content: The Act titled "Community and Postal Participation Act of 1998" provides guidelines for the relocation, closing, or consolidation of post offices. Section 404 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to require the Postal Service to provide 60 days notice to persons served by a post office before relocating, closing, or consolidating it. The notice must be in writing, hand-delivered or mailed, and published in newspapers within the zip codes served. The Postal Service must provide 60 days notice before relocating, closing, or consolidating a post office. Persons served by the post office can offer alternative proposals within this period. The Postal Service will make a final determination after a hearing where affected individuals can provide testimony. The Postal Service must consider various factors when deciding on the relocation, closing, or consolidation of a post office, including its location in a downtown area, community impact, opposition from the community, effects on employees, and alignment with government policy. The Postal Service must consider factors like economic savings, negotiations with affected parties, management contributions, post office adequacy, exploration of alternatives, and other relevant factors when deciding on post office relocation, closing, or consolidation. The Postal Service must consider various factors when deciding to relocate, close, or consolidate a post office, including any necessary factors determined by the Postal Service. Any decision must be in writing and include findings on the required considerations. The Postal Service must respond to alternative proposals in a consolidated report and make it available to the public at the post office in question. The Postal Service must provide a written decision on relocating, closing, or consolidating a post office, considering various factors. Any decision can be appealed to the Postal Rate Commission within 60 days of the report being made available. The Commission will review the determination within 120 days if an appeal is made. The Postal Rate Commission reviews Postal Service decisions on post office relocations, closures, or consolidations within 120 days of an appeal. The Commission can set aside any Postal Service determination that is arbitrary, capricious, or unsupported by substantial evidence. It may affirm the decision or send the matter back for further consideration. The Postal Rate Commission can review Postal Service decisions on post office relocations, closures, or consolidations within 120 days of an appeal. The Commission may suspend the Postal Service's determination until the final disposition of the appeal. Judicial review is not applicable to determinations made by the Commission. If a community has stricter procedures for addressing post office changes, those procedures will be followed instead of the standard procedures outlined in the subsection. The Postal Service must comply with zoning laws and the National Historic Preservation Act when relocating, closing, or consolidating post offices. The Postal Service must consider the community impact and existing facilities when creating new postal facilities, in addition to complying with zoning laws and the National Historic Preservation Act for relocations or closures.
